explanations.A: The power that 10 is raised to is different for each bracket, namely −3 and −4. This means that the 3 of 3.2 and 4 of 4.7, for example, have different place values. We could write the values as normal numbers to show the issue better: 0.0032 − 0.00047 = 0.00273 = 2.73 × 10^(−3). However, this can be time consuming, especially if the powers are very large. Another way of tackling the problems is to ensure the powers are to the same value and then factorise: 3.2 × 10^(−3) − 4.7 × 10^(−4) = 3.2 × 10^(−3) − 0.47 × 10^(−3) = 10^(−3) × (3.2 − 0.47) = 2.73 × 10^(−3)
explanations.B: I think you have added the numbers and added the powers. Use the powers to find the place value of each of the digits, line them up and then do the subtraction.
explanations.C: I think you have subtracted the numbers and subtracted the powers. Think about the place value of each of the digits, and use this to line up the numbers before you do the subtraction
explanations.D: Almost, just be careful with the borrowing
